A poster of Cambridge Analytica's CEO Alexander Nix at the firm's office in London | Daniel Leal-Olivas/AFP via Getty Images Cambridge Analytica academic who mined Facebook data: I’m a ‘scapegoat’ Researcher Aleksander Kogan claimed he had ‘no knowledge’ of data’s use.

"The events of the past week have been a total shell shock, and my view is that I'm being basically used as a scapegoat by both Facebook and Cambridge Analytica when... we thought we were doing something that was really normal," Kogan told BBC 4's Today Program.

Aleksandr Kogan, the Cambridge University researcher at the center of Facebook's data breach allegations, said today he is being used as a "scapegoat" by the social network and Cambridge Analytica, the analytics firm that acquired the data.
Cambridge Analytica whistleblower Christopher Wylie last week told the Observer that data collected by an app Kogan created was used target voters in the 2016 U.S. presidential election.
Cambridge Analytica has "exaggerated" the accuracy of the data collected, according to Kogan, who said the data was more likely to hurt Trump's campaign.
Asked whether it was possible the firm used the data to assist Donald Trump's campaign, Kogan told the BBC: "It's certainly possible but ...
"We were assured by Cambridge Analytica that everything was perfectly legal and within the terms of service," he said.
"One of the great mistakes I did here was I just didn’t ask enough questions," Kogan said.
The firm mined the information of about 50 million Facebook users, according to Wylie.
Cambridge Analytica has claimed Kogan came to the firm with the idea for the app.
He added that his values don't align with those of the U.S. president.
Kogan denied this, saying the firm approached him.
I truly don't have any knowledge of that."
